original:
A Walrasian equilibrium, also known as a competitive equilibrium, in an exchange economy is defined as a vector of consumption bundles and a price vector, denoted as \( (y_1, \ldots, y_{N-1}, p) \), that satisfies the following conditions:

1.    \[
   \sum y_i \leq \sum w_i
   \]

2.    \[
   p \cdot y_i \leq p \cdot w_i
   \]

3.    \[
   p \cdot y_i \leq p \cdot w_i
   \]
   This implies that if there exists an alternative consumption bundle \( z \) such that \( V_i(z) > V_i(y_i) \), then it must hold that:
   \[
   p \cdot z > p \cdot w_i \geq p \cdot y_i
   \]


Arrow and Debreu introduced a method to transition from an exchange economy to an abstract economy. In this framework, an \( (N-1) \)-agent exchange economy can be redefined as an \( N \)-agent abstract economy by incorporating an additional agent known as the market maker or market

Arrow and Debreu introduced a method to transition from an exchange economy to an abstract economy. In this framework, an \( (N-1) \)-agent exchange economy can be redefined as an \( N \)-agent abstract clearing by incorporating an additional agent known for the market maker or market
